sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying coil
message_1: A physics student needs to calculate the magnetic field at a point on the axis of a circular coil carrying a current of 5A. The radius of the coil is 0.2m and the point on the axis is at a distance of 0.4m from the center of the coil. Given that the coil has 10 turns, what is the magnitude of the magnetic field at this point?
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a point on the axis of a circular coil, we can use the formula:

B = (μ₀ * I * N * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, N is the number of turns, R is the radius of the coil, and x is the distance from the center of the coil to the point on the axis.

Given the values:
I = 5 A
N = 10 turns
R = 0.2 m
x = 0.4 m

We can plug these values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 5 A * 10 * (0.2 m)²) / (2 * ((0.2 m)² + (0.4 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (4π × 10^(-7) * 5 * 10 * 0.04) / (2 * (0.04 + 0.16)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-6)) / (2 * (0.2)^(3/2))

B ≈ 2π × 10^(-5) T

The magnitude of the magnetic field at the point on the axis is approximately 2π × 10^(-5) T.
